para.paratext: The Fourth, Fifth, and Sixth Amendments of the United States Constitution grant criminal defendants and other witnesses certain “constitutional privileges,” which protect them from being compelled to provide self-incriminating testimony[1] and from having evidence secured in violation of a constitutional rights used against them.[2] The Georgia Constitution provides similar protections.[3] State courts are bound by the United States Supreme Court's interpretations of the United States Constitution, and states must grant constitutional privileges to the extent provided by federal law,[4] but may choose to offer a more extensive privilege.[5] In many instances, Georgia courts have done just that.

The United States Constitution clearly provides an evidentiary privilege against self-incrimination and evidence secured in violation of the privilege is not admissible against an accused. The Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution states, “No person … shall be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself.” The Georgia Constitution also states, “No person shall be compelled to give testimony tending in any manner to be self-incriminating.”[6] The Georgia General Assembly codified the privilege as to criminal defendants in O.C.G.A. § 24-5-506 and as to other witnesses in O.C.G.A. § 24-5-505.
O.C.G.A. § 24-5-506 provides:
(a) No person who is charged in any criminal proceeding with the commission of any criminal offense shall be compellable to give evidence for or against himself or herself.

(b) If an accused in a criminal proceeding wishes to testify and announces in open court his or her intention to do so, the accused may so testify. If an accused testifies, he or she shall be sworn as any other witness and, except as provided in Code Sections 24-6-608 and 24-6-609, may be examined and cross-examined as any other witness. The failure of an accused to testify shall create no presumption against the accused, and no comment shall be made because of such failure.
O.C.G.A. § 24-5-505 provides:

(a) No party or witness shall be required to testify as to any matter which may incriminate or tend to incriminate such party or witness or which shall tend to bring infamy, disgrace, or public contempt upon such party or witness or any member of such party or witness's family.

(b) Except in proceedings in which a judgment creditor or judgment creditor's successor in interest seeks post judgment discovery involving a judgment debtor pursuant to Code Section 9-11-69, no party or witness shall be required to testify as to any matter which shall tend to work a forfeiture of his or her estate.
(c) No official persons shall be called on to disclose any state matters of which the policy of the state and the interest of the community require concealment.

In Malloy v. Hogan,[7] the United States Supreme Court held that the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution made the privilege against self-incrimination in the Fifth Amendment, along with the entire body of federal interpretation, apply to the states as well as the federal government. This required the states to grant as broad a privilege against self-incrimination as the federal privilege. This had little effect in Georgia because the Georgia privilege has always been broader than the federal privilege with a few minor exceptions.

However, in Murphy v. Waterfront Commission,[8] the Supreme Court made some changes which affected Georgia practice. Prior to Murphy, the privilege against self-incrimination had been available only where an answer would incriminate the individual in the jurisdiction under whose sovereign authority an answer was required. Thus, an individual required to answer under Georgia law could not refuse to answer because his answer might incriminate him under federal law. The federal privilege could not be claimed in a Georgia court, and the Georgia privilege could not be claimed in a federal court.

This rule was completely changed by Murphy v. Waterfront Commission, which allowed a witness in federal jurisdiction to refuse to answer because his answer might incriminate him in a state jurisdiction. Therefore, a witness in a Georgia court can claim his privilege against self-incrimination if an answer might tend to incriminate him under federal law and vice versa. Although Murphy did not expressly address the issue of privilege between two state jurisdictions, courts have since granted the privilege under such circumstances.[9]

In U.S. v. Balsys,[10] the United States Supreme Court disallowed application of the privilege in cases in which a criminal defendant feared criminal sanction in another country. The Court held that fear of prosecution by a foreign government was beyond the scope of the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination.[11] The Supreme Court did reiterate, however, that the privilege against self-incrimination can be asserted domestically “in any proceeding, civil or criminal, administrative or judicial, investigatory or adjudicatory, in which the witness reasonably believes that the information sought, or discoverable as a result of his testimony, could be used in a subsequent state or federal criminal proceeding.”[12]
U.S. Const. Amend. IV, V and VI.
Ga. Const. Art. 1, § 1, ¶ I, ¶ IX, ¶ XI, ¶ XVI.
Ga. Const. Art. I, § 1, ¶ XVI.
Murphy v. Waterfront Commission, 378 U.S. 52, 84 S. Ct. 1594, 12 L. Ed. 2d 678 (1964).

See, e.g., U.S. v. Gaitan-Acevedo, 148 F.3d 577, 49 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 590, 1998 FED App. 0143P (6th Cir. 1998) (co-defendant properly allowed to invoke Fifth Amendment privilege where plea agreement did not protect him from prosecution in other jurisdictions for crimes committed in another state). See also U.S. v. Balsys, 524 U.S. 666, 672, 118 S. Ct. 2218, 141 L. Ed. 2d 575, 49 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 371 (1998).

See also U.S. v. Gecas, 120 F.3d 1419 (11th Cir. 1997) (resident alien could not invoke Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination based upon real and substantial likelihood of prosecution and conviction in Israel, Germany, and Lithuania).
